newsitem.title: USA: Liberty says court denied Putnam injunction.
newsitem.headline: Liberty says court denied Putnam injunction.

text.p: A Massachusetts court denied a preliminary injunction against three former executives with Putnam Investments who quit to join Liberty Financial Co Inc and its units, Liberty said on Thursday.

Putnam alleged in a February lawsuit that Kevin O'Shea, the chief executive of Liberty unit Colonial Group and a former Putnam executive, recruited three former colleagues, which violated non-soliciation agreements.
The three executives are James Tambone, Louis Tasiopoulos, both managing directors with Liberty, and Kevin O'Shea, managing director of Colonial Group unit Colonial Investment Services.

"I am unpersuaded on this record of the likelihood of the plaintiff's (Putnam's) success on the merits of its claim that solicitation in fact took place," Middlesex Superior Court Judge James McHugh wrote in an opinion released by Liberty.

"We are pleased and gratified that Judge McHugh's ruling in this case is consistent with our position that no violations of the Putnam non-solicitation agreements occured," Liberty said in a statement.
A Putnam spokeswoman said the company was confident the court would rule in its favor when the case proceeds.
"We are confident and expect our position to be upheld when the facts are fully heard at the court," said Nancy Fisher.
